Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Biological impacts of climate change: testing hypotheses with collections and long-term data
Award.AbstractNarration: A Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Sites award has been made to the University of California, Santa Cruz (UCSC) to provide research training for eight students for eight weeks during the summers of 2013-2015. Climate change, the overriding environmental issue of our time, causes drastic changes in the distributions and abundances of many species and potentially threatens peoples' ways of life. This REU will train students to use critical tools to understand mechanisms underlying biological responses to climate change, including: 1) physiological/ecological limits of species; 2) changes in species' interactions; and 3) hypothesis testing that enables one to discriminate between climate change and other natural or anthropogenic factors affecting species diversity and geographical distributions. Students will work on a diversity of organisms, systems, and specific questions guided by mentors from UCSC's Dept. of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology and the Dept. of Environmental Studies, and several regional organizations. The common threads among projects include 1) testing hypotheses; 2) assembling long-term data sets from museums and faculty research; 3) measuring key physiological/behavioral traits or ecological interactions; 4) predicting changes in species' distributions and/or ecosystems based on future climate scenarios; and 5) conducting field work to ground-truth their predictions. This REU will select and train 24 undergraduates, including many minority students, based on their academic records and research potential. All students will be mentored to help them improve communication skills, discover resources for their education and careers, and recognize and value their own contributions to science. The REU program includes talks, discussions and workshops on methods and concepts key to their projects, and relevant field trips. These students will also join with an existing UCSC undergraduate research program targeting minority students in STEM disciplines for workshops on scientific ethics and communication. Students will be tracked to determine their continued interest in science, career paths, and lasting influences of their REU experience. The program will be assessed by various means, including an REU common assessment tool. More information is available by visiting http://reu.eeb.ucsc.edu/, or by contacting the PI (Dr. Barry Sinervo at lizardrps@gmail.com) or the co-PI (Dr. Laurel Fox at fox@ucsc.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Climate change has become the overriding environmental issue of our time, leading to drastic changes in the physiologies/behaviors of individual animals and plants, in ecological interactions and in the distributions and abundances of many species, and potentially threatening peoples’ way of life. The chief scientific goal of our REU was that the students learn critical tools for understanding the mechanisms behind the biological consequences of climate change. These include: 1) species physiological/ecological limits and their assumed abiotic drivers; 2) alternative biotic explanations for species’ distributional limits; and 3) hypothesis testing that enables us to discriminate between climate change vs. other natural or anthropogenic factors that may affect the biota.

Students worked on a diversity of organisms, systems, and specific questions guided by mentors from UCSC’s Departments of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology and Environmental Studies. The common threads among their projects were 1) testing hypotheses; 2) assembling historical data from museums and long-term datasets; 3) measuring key physiological or behavioral traits, or ecological interactions; 4) predicting changes in species distributions and/or ecosystems from future climate scenarios; and 5) conducting field work to ground-truth their predictions at salient UC Natural Reserve System (NRS) field stations or other natural sites along coastal California.

We mentored a total of 26 students in all stages of their projects, and helped them to communicate more effectively using a range of media, to discover resources for their future education and careers, and to recognize and value their own contributions to science. We enriched their experience with talks, discussions and workshops on methods and concepts key to their projects, and with relevant field trips. We also joined with an existing undergraduate research program at UCSC, targeting minority students in various science, technology, engineering, and math disciplines for workshops on scientific ethics and communication.         

In summary, our program trained 26 undergraduates, many from underrepresented minority groups, in state-of-the-art methods related to the biological impacts of climate change. Our students can contribute to understanding these impacts because their work was based on testing specific hypotheses about mechanisms, not only recording changes in species’ abundances and distributions.
